Description: Terracotta reclining ithyphallic figure. A naked man, modelled in the round, reclining with his feet extending to his left on a plain subrectangular plinth, and leaning on a cubical block. Possibly Harpocrates, though the physique looks too mature. He holds a pot to his right side and his large phallus rises up to pass under his left arm and to curve up to his left shoulder at the back. Solid; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a thick grey-brown core and some white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Holding pot as found on Harpocrates figures of the Ptolemaic period. GR1973,0501. 5, GR1973,0501. 6, GR1973,0501. 12, GR1973,0501. 13, GR1973,0501. 19, GR1973,0501. 20, GR1973,0501. 24 and GR1973,0501. 50 are similar in style, fabric and subject as NA598 from Naukratis, currently in Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology. Naukratis is the most likely source for these based on the style, fabric, date of the figures and history of the Greece and Rome department’s holdings of Egyptian material (73% are from Naukratis).
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3214)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.214) (Phase 1)
Condition: The figure is much damaged, lost at the front from the navel down, together with the plinth at the man’s left; lost also at the back from the lower left thigh; the head is gone and the tip of the phallus is injured.
